story.storykicker: Unlike humans and other animals or plants, these partially immortal species do not die just by ageing.
story.storybody:
Biologically immortal organisms are the organisms that possess a stable or decreasing rate of mortality than the usual mortal organisms. There have been plenty of species reported which really are technically immortal.The death of these unicellular, multicellular and few vertebrate species depend on the disease, situation or environment they encounter. These species, unlike humans and other animals or plants, do not die simply because they get old.

Let's have a look at 5 plants and animals that can live forever:

Bristlecone Pine   

{mosimage} 

Pinus longaeva is usually found at high altitude in the barren regions of the Western United States. It is one among the three species belonging to the pine trees family, that have a long duration of life and is highly volatile to harsh weather and bad soils. The Great Basin bristlecone pine is 5,000 years old, marking it as the oldest known individual of any species.

Ocean Quahog (Ming)

{mosimage} 

Ming is the nickname given to a sample of the ocean quahog mollusc that was dragged off the coast of Iceland in 2006. The age of the mollusc is accurately determined based on the count taken on annual growth lines in the shell. Born in the Ming dynasty, It is the oldest individual animal with a lifespan of 507 years.

Hydra

{mosimage} 

Hydra is a breed of small fresh-water animals which are native to the temperature and tropical regions. The miniature animal undergoes morphallaxis (tissue regeneration) when injured or severed. Biologists attain special interest in Hydra due to their regenerative ability.

Jelly Fish

{mosimage} 

Jellyfish are free swimming marine animals with a gelatinous umbrella-shaped bell and trailing tentacles. They can be found in every ocean and use their bell to pulsate for locomotion along with stinging tentacles to capture prey. Jellyfish are the oldest multi-organ animals to have sailed the seas for at least 500 million years, and possibly 700 million years or more.

American Lobster

{mosimage} 

The American lobster, also known as true lobster is a breed of clawed lobster found in the Atlantic coast of North America. It has a length of 64 cm and weighs over 20 kilograms, making the heaviest crustacean in the world and also the heaviest of all living arthropods. They have the ability to regenerate their claws and limbs during adulthood.

Interested in General Knowledge and Current Affairs? Click here to stay informed and know what is happening around the world with our G.K. and Current Affairs section.
